LLOY.description:
Lloyds Banking Group plc is a UK-focused financial services group that provides everyday retail banking, business banking and insurance/retirement products to individuals, small businesses and larger companies, mainly in the United Kingdom. ([lloydsbankinggroup.com](https://www.lloydsbankinggroup.com/who-we-are.html?utm_source=openai))

Most of its revenue comes from earning interest on lending (especially mortgages and business loans) versus what it pays on customer deposits, plus fees and commissions from services like card payments, current accounts and wealth/insurance products. It serves customers through well-known brands including Lloyds Bank, Halifax and Bank of Scotland, and it also has a large life and pensions business under Scottish Widows. ([lloydsbankinggroup.com](https://www.lloydsbankinggroup.com/who-we-are.html?utm_source=openai))

Operationally, it distributes products through a mix of digital channels (mobile/online banking) and a branch network across Britain, with an ongoing industry-wide shift toward more digital servicing. Its commercial banking arm supports UK businesses with lending, cash management and related banking services, while its insurance and long-term savings activities focus on pensions, life insurance and investments for people planning for retirement and other long-term goals. ([lloydsbankinggroup.com](https://www.lloydsbankinggroup.com/who-we-are.html?utm_source=openai))
LLOY.special_sits:
Here are the **material, decision‑relevant special‑situation items** for Lloyds Banking Group plc within the last 12 months or upcoming. Only genuinely material developments are flagged; routine items are omitted.

---

**1. Material Litigation / Regulatory Action – Motor Finance (Car‑Loan) Scandal**  
Lloyds has substantially increased its provisions for compensation related to the UK motor finance (car loans) commission scandal:

- In February 2025, Lloyds set aside an additional **£700 million**, bringing total provisions to nearly **£1.2 billion**, following an adverse court judgment and escalating FCA investigations. This slashed pre‑tax profits by about 20%. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2025/feb/20/lloyds-puts-aside-another-700m-for-compensation-over-car-finance-scandal?utm_source=openai))  
- More recently, in October 2025, the bank increased its provision by another **£800 million**, raising total reserves to **£1.95 billion**. This reflects heightened expectations of liability under a potential FCA redress scheme estimated to cost the industry up to £12.4 billion. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2025/oct/13/lloyds-puts-aside-extra-800m-car-finance-compensation-historical-claims?utm_source=openai))  

These charges are materially large relative to Lloyds’ profit base and potentially threaten earnings, capital allocation, and investor sentiment.

---

**2. Regulatory Inquiry – Staff Data Usage in Pay Talks (Privacy/ICO)**  
Lloyds is under scrutiny by the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) for allegedly accessing aggregated banking data from **30,000 staff accounts** during pay negotiations. If found in breach of data protection rules, the bank could face fines of up to **4% of annual turnover**, equating to a potential **£1.36 billion** based on 2024 earnings. The ICO is reportedly making inquiries to assess whether a full investigation is warranted. Staff unions may also pursue legal action depending on outcomes. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/13/lloyds-banking-group-staff-data-pay-talks-ico-accounts?utm_source=openai))  

This is a potentially high‑impact governance and regulatory risk, with possible financial and reputational consequences.

---

**3. Major Litigation – Arena Television Fraud Lawsuit**  
Lloyds faces a **£285 million lawsuit** from the liquidators of Arena Television, alleging that the bank enabled a large‑scale fraud by facilitating facility arrangements based on fake or non‑existent collateral. The firm denies wrongdoing and intends to contest the claim; investigations by the SFO and French authorities are ongoing. ([thetimes.co.uk](https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/arena-television-liquidators-sue-lloyds-for-285m-over-fraud-509wvb706?utm_source=openai))  

Although smaller in magnitude than the motor finance provision, this case risks reputational and financial exposure and raises questions about risk controls.

---

**4. Major Litigation – Tax Ruling by HMRC**  
In February 2025, Lloyds was ordered by a London tribunal to pay approximately **£1 billion** in tax following a failed appeal against HMRC’s challenge to its claim for relief on Irish property loan losses. The bank plans to appeal the ruling, potentially up to the UK Supreme Court; though it intends to offset the outlay with a tax asset, this remains a material unresolved liability. ([ft.com](https://www.ft.com/content/390c2f08-c033-4756-80e7-b60645e9450b?utm_source=openai))  

This is a significant impact on financials and may affect capital planning depending on appeal outcomes.

---

**5. Major Buyback – Large Capital Return Completed**  
Lloyds has completed a substantial share repurchase programme:

- Between February 21, 2025, and December 8, 2025, the bank repurchased **2,204,109,740 ordinary shares** under an authorized **£1.7 billion buyback programme**. ([stocktitan.net](https://www.stocktitan.net/sec-filings/LYG%2CLLDTF%2CLLOBF/6-k-lloyds-banking-group-plc-current-report-foreign-issuer-751eed4dd391.html?utm_source=openai))  

This is a **material capital structure event** (category (d))—the scale significantly reduces equity outstanding and represents a major capital return, potentially impacting future earnings per share (EPS) and shareholder value.

---

**Summary of Decision‑Relevant Special Situations**

- **Motor finance scandal provisions** (~£1.95 billion): Material and ongoing liability affecting earnings/reserves.
- **ICO inquiry on staff data usage**: Potential multi‑hundred‑million‑pound fine with governance implications.
- **Arena Television fraud litigation** (£285 million): Material legal exposure, reputational risk.
- **£1 billion tax liability (HMRC ruling)**: Significant contingent liability; resolution pending escalation.
- **£1.7 billion share buyback completed**: Major capital return and structural equity reduction.

---

If you’d like deeper analysis on any of these—such as estimated financial impacts, timelines, or risk modeling—just let me know.

WJG.description:
Watkin Jones plc develops, builds, and manages residential-for-rent homes across the UK—including purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA), build-to-rent (BTR) properties, and affordable housing—primarily for institutional investors.

Watkin Jones operates a capital-light “forward-sale” model: it sources urban sites, secures planning permission, and constructs developments, which it then sells to investors rather than holding on its balance sheet ([watkinjonesplc.com](https://watkinjonesplc.com/news-insights/2024/260-bed-pbsa-development-in-bristol-forward-sold-to-leading-real-estate-investor/?utm_source=openai)). Its in-house construction and management capabilities, particularly through its Fresh division, allow it to deliver projects efficiently and manage them post-completion for clients ([watkinjonesplc.com](https://watkinjonesplc.com/our-business/what-we-do/?utm_source=openai)).

The company is a market leader in UK PBSA, having delivered tens of thousands of student beds since 1999 ([watkinjonesplc.com](https://watkinjonesplc.com/news-insights/2024/260-bed-pbsa-development-in-bristol-forward-sold-to-leading-real-estate-investor/?utm_source=openai)). It is expanding BTR operations and continues in affordable housing, all within the same forward-sale framework ([watkinjonesplc.com](https://watkinjonesplc.com/about-us/our-strategy/?utm_source=openai)). Fresh handles ongoing property management—covering lettings, compliance, marketing, customer relations, and finance—providing an “end-to-end” service for investors ([watkinjonesplc.com](https://watkinjonesplc.com/our-business/what-we-do/?utm_source=openai)).

Revenue is derived from forward sales of developments and from management fees collected through Fresh. The company does not retain significant real estate ownership, minimizing capital risk. Its key strength lies in controlling both development and post-completion management, supported by strong institutional relationships and internal execution.
WJG.special_sits:
Here are the **material decision-relevant events** for **Watkin Jones Plc** from the past 12 months and near-term, aligned with your special-situation criteria:

1. **Major Insider Buying (Material?)**
   - **Event**: Significant insider purchases by key executives.
   - **Details**: On January 9, 2026, Chairman Alan Giddins acquired 148,000 shares at approximately 26.63p each, totaling **£39.4k**, increasing his stake to about **0.4% of issued share capital** ([sharecast.com](https://www.sharecast.com/news/dealings-round-up/director-dealings--18666092.html?utm_source=openai)). CFO Simon Jones also made multiple purchases totaling approximately **£25k** across various transactions ([sharecast.com](https://www.sharecast.com/news/dealings-round-up/director-dealings--18666092.html?utm_source=openai)).
   - **Assessment**: These purchases are **below** the material thresholds of **>£100k and >0.5% ownership**. Thus, **do not flag** under “major insider dealings.”

2. **No Takeover or Strategic Review Indications**
   - No announced offers, strategic reviews, or credible takeover interest were identified in searches.

3. **No Transformational M&A, Disposals, or Breakups in Last 12 Months**
   - No major asset sales, spin-offs, or corporate restructuring reported in the period.

4. **No Material Buybacks, Special Returns, or Dividends**
   - No buybacks or special dividends approaching materiality thresholds (>10% of shares or market cap).

5. **No Delisting, Liquidation, or Going-Concer**n
   - No indications of delisting or wind-down processes.

6. **Litigation or Regulatory Events**
   - While there is a sizable building safety provision (c.£46 million), this appears to be a structural provisioning issue, not a discrete new regulatory/litigation event within the last year. It doesn’t meet the category threshold of **“major litigation / regulatory action”** under your framework.

7. **Going-Concern / Solvency**
   - FY25 results show robust liquidity: **£80.4 million gross cash**, **£70.5 million net cash**, and total liquidity of **£130 million** including undrawn facilities. Forward-sold revenue of c.£340 million secures FY26 cash flows ([joshthompson.co.uk](https://joshthompson.co.uk/investing/watkin-jones-resilient-fy25-results-2bn-pipeline/?utm_source=openai)).
   - No going-concern warnings or covenant breaches identified.

8. **Governance or Leadership Disruption**
   - No CEO/CFO departures, audit or broker resignations, or qualified opinions have occurred in the past year.

9. **Capital Structure Events**
   - No significant equity or debt issuance that meets the threshold for materiality.

10. **Accounting Restatements**
    - No restatements or auditor issues found.

11. **Material Strategic or Financial Risks**
    - Building safety provision remains a meaningful legacy liability (c.£46.4 million), with a projected cash outflow of ~£20 million in FY26 ([joshthompson.co.uk](https://joshthompson.co.uk/investing/watkin-jones-resilient-fy25-results-2bn-pipeline/?utm_source=openai)). This is a known ongoing issue, not newly flagged.

 **Conclusion**: **No decision-relevant special-situation items** have emerged within the past 12 months for Watkin Jones Plc that meet the materiality criteria specified. The company appears operationally resilient, with strong liquidity and forward revenue visibility.

VTY.description:
Vistry Group PLC is a UK residential developer that builds and sells new homes across the UK, supplying both private homebuyers and “partner” customers such as housing associations, local authorities and large rental landlords. ([gov.uk](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/homes-england-and-vistry-group-sign-long-term-joint-venture?utm_source=openai))

A large share of Vistry’s output is “partner funded”: it agrees developments with partners and delivers homes that are pre-sold (typically affordable housing or homes sold in bulk to a rental investor), which can make demand more predictable than relying only on individual buyers. It also sells homes on the open market through brands including Bovis Homes, Linden Homes and Countryside Homes. ([investegate.co.uk](https://www.investegate.co.uk/announcement/rns/vistry-group--vty/full-year-results-for-the-year-ended-31-dec-2024/8797108?utm_source=openai))

Vistry also has in-house, off-site manufacturing (“Vistry Works”) that produces timber-frame wall panels and other components to help build homes faster and with less on-site labour; its factories are in Leicester, Warrington and the East Midlands. ([vistrycareers.co.uk](https://www.vistrycareers.co.uk/about-us/vistry-works/?utm_source=openai))
VTY.special_sits:
Here are the **decision-relevant special-situation developments** for **Vistry Group PLC** over the past 12 months (and any noteworthy upcoming items). Only **material events** are flagged:

---

##  Material Special Situations

1. **Substantial Share Buyback Program (Buybacks of Own Shares)**
   - Vistry has executed a **significant open-market share repurchase program**. From June through December 2025, it repurchased several batches of shares, ranging between **~39,600 to ~48,000 shares** per transaction, at average prices between **~622p and ~661p**, totaling hundreds of thousands of shares cancelled or held in treasury ([investegate.info](https://www.investegate.info/announcement/rns/vistry-group--vty/transaction-in-own-shares/9227733?utm_source=openai)).
   - While substantial in aggregate, the total shares repurchased represent **only a small fraction** of total shares outstanding (~320 million), far below the 10% threshold both of share count and market cap required to be decision-altering.  
   - **Conclusion**: Material effort, but **does not cross** the threshold for a “major buyback” warranting a flag under (d).  
   → **Omit** (i.e., do not report as material).

2. **Directive Profit Warnings, Restructuring, and Dividend Cancellation**
   - Vistry issued a **third profit warning** in late 2024, culminating in a dramatic profit downgrade (from ~£430 m forecast down to ~£250 m) and removal from the FTSE 100 ([marketwatch.com](https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-home-builder-issued-its-third-profit-warning-in-three-months-its-stock-is-tanking-b8f1bc62?utm_source=openai)).
   - **Restructuring** followed: merging regional divisions (from six to three), tightening cost controls after a £165 m overrun, and cancellation of the final dividend, historically a steady return ([ft.com](https://www.ft.com/content/6d8fd6cb-fe78-44ec-9b57-ab0dc1228cf7?utm_source=openai)).
   - These events reflect **serious operational and governance challenges** and **material value erosion**, but occurred mostly before the 12-month window (prior to January 15 2025).
   - **Conclusion**: Outside the 12-month scope; therefore, **omit**.

3. **First-Half 2025 Profit Slump; Dependence on Government Affordable Housing Funding**
   - In July 2025, Vistry announced a **~34% drop** in H1 adjusted pre-tax profit (to ~£80 m from ~£120.7 m) due to rising costs and affordability pressures ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/british-homebuilder-vistrys-first-half-pre-tax-profit-slumps-soft-market-2025-07-10/?utm_source=openai)).
   - However, the company expects recovery in H2 driven by a substantial **£10 bn UK government affordable housing investment**, signaling dependency on policy tailwinds but not yet materializing in control, capital structure, or governance shift.
   - **Conclusion**: Not material under the predefined categories — **omit**.

4. **Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) Investigation Settlement**
   - Vistry was under CMA investigation for suspected anti-competitive information sharing. In June–July 2025, Vistry (and peers) offered **£100 m towards affordable housing** plus industry reform to settle the probe without admitting liability; the CMA confirmed termination of the investigation by October 30, 2025 ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vistry_Group?utm_source=openai)).
   - This represents both a material financial commitment and regulatory resolution, potentially influencing enterprise value and licence to operate.
   - **Conclusion**: **Flag as material under (f) Major litigation/regulatory action**.

---

##  Summary Output

**Special Situations Identified (Decision-Relevant):**

- **CMA Investigation Settlement (Regulatory Action)**
  - **What happened**: Vistry resolved a prolonged regulatory investigation into suspected anti-competitive conduct.
  - **Details**: In mid-2025, Vistry and other UK housebuilders offered £100 million (to support affordable housing and implement industry reforms) to settle with the Competition & Markets Authority (CMA). The CMA confirmed it dropped the investigation by **October 30, 2025**. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vistry_Group?utm_source=openai))
  - **Why it matters**: This removes a significant legal overhang, clinches a large conditional financial commitment, and may change industry dynamics. Material from a valuation/governance standpoint.

---

If no other items meet materiality thresholds, then that is the sole flag.

WOSG.description:
Watches of Switzerland Group PLC is a UK-based luxury retailer that sells high-end watches and jewelry through its own-brand showrooms, mono‑brand boutiques, and online platforms to affluent consumers and collectors in the UK and US.

The company operates a multi-channel retail business featuring a network of nearly 200 showrooms across the UK and the US—including multi‑brand stores, dedicated mono‑brand boutiques for premium brands like Rolex, OMEGA, and TAG Heuer, as well as travel‑retail outlets in Heathrow airport—and seven e‑commerce websites ([thewosgroupplc.com](https://www.thewosgroupplc.com/group/?utm_source=openai)). Watches of Switzerland generates most of its revenue from luxury watch sales—82% in the fiscal year 2025, equating to £1.65 billion total revenue—and also earns from jewelry, pre‑owned watches via Analog:Shift, servicing, and associated services like product insurance ([thewosgroupplc.com](https://www.thewosgroupplc.com/?utm_source=openai)). Its customers include high-net-worth individuals and collectors, and the company leverages exclusive retail agreements and premium presentation to attract discerning buyers ([thewosgroupplc.com](https://www.thewosgroupplc.com/group/business-model/?utm_source=openai)).

Revenue is earned through retail sales across physical and digital channels. The Group’s competitive edge lies in its long-standing brand partnerships, upscale showroom environments, and integrated IT systems that support inventory, CRM, and rapid expansion ([thewosgroupplc.com](https://www.thewosgroupplc.com/group/business-model/?utm_source=openai)). The acquisition of Roberto Coin’s North American distribution rights and the editorial outlet Hodinkee are strategic moves to deepen its jewelry offering and digital reach ([thewosgroupplc.com](https://www.thewosgroupplc.com/group/history/?utm_source=openai)).
WOSG.special_sits:
Here are the **decision‑relevant special‑situation items** for Watches of Switzerland Group PLC within the last 12 months (relative to January 15 2026):

1. **Share Buy‑Back Programme**  
   - **Confirmed event**: On March 10 2025, the company launched a £25 million share buy-back programme, intended to return surplus capital to shareholders; purchases would be cancelled. This follows a December 2024 refinancing that expanded its liquidity with a £150 million facility providing ~£50 million additional headroom.  
   - **Materiality**: While quantification relative to market cap or shares outstanding isn't specified, a £25 million repurchase is meaningful and could gradually impact share count and valuation.  
   ([investing.thisismoney.co.uk](https://investing.thisismoney.co.uk/rns/news/34929213?utm_source=openai))

2. **Acquisition of Hodinkee**  
   - **Confirmed event**: On October 4 2024, the Group acquired Hodinkee, a leading global digital platform for luxury watch enthusiasts, with ~22 million annual unique visitors and over 1 million social media followers. The acquisition is aimed at accelerating online leadership, particularly in the U.S., by integrating Hodinkee’s commercial activities with the Group’s e-commerce.  
   - **Materiality**: This is a transformational M&A, enhancing e‑commerce reach and content ecosystem in a high‑growth segment. Funded from existing facilities and stated not to materially impact leverage, but still decision‑relevant for valuation and strategic positioning.  
   ([cdn.financialreports.eu](https://cdn.financialreports.eu/financialreports/media/filings/5023/2024/RNS/5023_rns_2024-10-04_248c5173-a1cb-4894-973e-7dd4a86ef219.html?Expires=1731021424&Key-Pair-Id=K6QMJA61RGOXQ&Signature=LwXdzGr-AjB~qWfMaoazgCv6w2kV1NzklVwGXPVWoF1foRYcGbmDb1S3W9maLLSQwziIknCK4eZqeiRo0rdwEDqn0cxn0HeG4aDFaHFWND8Q8q~U0EfQ44BCXanzrBVoG0ApSs1ivhZxQpyHfcXXCKz6qhZiD7IkZ7LJ1I1165KKcPRD-BdOqhECyXc--WB3WaQQdvJl1lZ1PDMp7DbEYnqWehsFgO3DvP7fs5ZfK4RUqcm3Z~u6NcV7-ETAtfmLZTuwR1FPpvTejjtY7De4Cd8nSutOAjmM5b~k-G5RWYJus82QsVFs-YHA7E8mpI-yRWBVL80uHejFhpGgRTVabg__&utm_source=openai))

3. **Material Charges Impacting Profitability**  
   - **Confirmed event**: For the year ending April 27 2025, the company reported record revenue of £1.65 billion and adjusted EBIT of £150 million. However, pre‑tax profit dropped 18% to £76 million, due in part to a £43.6 million property impairment, higher finance costs, and showroom expansion investments. The outlook was clouded by rising U.S. tariffs, expected to squeeze margins further (flat to down up to 100 basis points), which triggered a share price drop.  
   - **Materiality**: The £43.6 million impairment is a one‑off charge of significance, directly impacting net income. Ongoing tariff pressure adds risk to future earnings and valuation.  
   ([thetimes.co.uk](https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/watches-of-switzerland-posts-record-revenue-but-profits-slide-7mjn0s7ml?utm_source=openai))

4. **Tariff‑Driven Margin Pressures**  
   - **Confirmed event**: On July 3 2025, the company warned that U.S. tariffs on Swiss imports could pressure profit margins in FY25, prompting an immediate ~6–8% share price decline. Management projected potential margin contraction if tariffs persisted.  
   - **Further confirmation**: In early September 2025, the Group reaffirmed that strong U.S. demand and elevated inventory levels from brand partners should mitigate tariff impacts for H1, reaffirming full‑year FY26 guidance.  
   - **Materiality**: Tariff policy is external but significantly impacts cost structure and margins, and creates operational uncertainty.  
   ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/british-retailer-watches-switzerland-forecasts-6-10-annual-revenue-growth-2025-07-03/?utm_source=openai))

5. **H1 FY26 Trading Update & Showroom Expansion**  
   - **Confirmed event**: On November 6 2025, the H1 trading update showed group revenue up ~10% (constant currency), with U.S. up ~20% and U.K. up ~2%. Adjusted EBIT was £66–68 million, with a slight margin contraction (~50 bps). The update outlined continuation of retail investments—including three new Roberto Coin mono‑brand boutiques (to open in New York and Las Vegas Q3 FY26) and a significant expansion of a Rolex boutique in Glasgow opening mid‑2026.  
   - **Materiality**: Strong growth and continued expansion are positive for momentum, though margin pressure continues. New showroom openings, particularly mono‑brand boutiques, could materially affect future revenue and positioning.  
   ([directorstalkinterviews.com](https://www.directorstalkinterviews.com/watches-of-switzerland-delivers-10-h1-revenue-growth-driven-by-strong-us-sales/4121224631?utm_source=openai))

---

**Summary**  
- **Material strategic capital allocation**: share buy-back (£25m).
- **Transformational M&A**: acquisition of Hodinkee (enhances digital presence).
- **Profit downgrades and impairments**: £43.6m property impairment and net income decline.
- **External macro risk**: U.S. tariffs pressuring margins; ongoing uncertainty.
- **Operational growth and expansion**: strong U.S. performance, boutique openings, especially Roberto Coin and Rolex expansions.

If you’d like deeper financial modeling or comparative analysis across peers, I’m ready to assist further.

AAF.description:
Airtel Africa Plc provides mobile voice, data and digital financial services across 14 countries in Africa, selling directly to consumers, small merchants and corporate customers.

The company operates and maintains mobile networks and spectrum licences to deliver prepaid and postpaid voice and internet access, fixed wireless/broadband in some markets, and enterprise connectivity and managed services to businesses. A key product is Airtel Money, a digital wallet that lets users send/receive funds, pay bills and accept merchant payments; the business also earns from airtime/data sales, interconnect fees, device distribution and transaction fees on its payments platform. Airtel Africa is listed
AAF.special_sits: I don’t currently have live web access in this session. To complete your request I need to search recent filings, RNS/press releases and credible press (last 12 months + any announced upcoming items). May I proceed to run a live search and compile only materially decision‑relevant items per your criteria (I will flag rumours clearly)?

AAL.description:
Anglo American plc is a London‑headquartered multinational mining company that extracts and sells bulk and precious commodities—chiefly copper, iron ore, metallurgical and thermal coal, nickel, platinum‑group metals and diamonds—to industrial buyers and commodity traders around the world.

The company operates and develops mines and processing plants (exploration → development → extraction → milling to produce mineral concentrates or saleable ore → shipment) across South America, southern Africa, Australia and Canada. Its product mix includes copper concentrates and cathode for smelters and fabricators, iron ore for steelmakers, metallurgical coal for steelmaking and thermal coal for power, platinum‑group metals used in autocatalysts and industrial applications, and diamonds marketed through its De Beers interests to the jewelry trade. Revenue comes from commodity sales under a mix of spot purchases, long‑term contracts and joint‑venture offtake arrangements; Anglo American also invests in project development and periodically adjusts its asset portfolio through disposals or expansions.
AAL.special_sits:
I can do this, but I don’t currently have live web access. To reliably identify material, decision‑relevant items in the past 12 months or upcoming (per your rules) I need to search current filings and press coverage (RNS/SENS/press releases, company reports, UK filings, major press).

Options — please pick one:
1) I run a live web search now (I will pull RNS/press releases, regulator filings and credible press, then return a short list of only material items with sources). Confirm and I’ll proceed.
2) Use my existing knowledge (cutoff Jun 2024). I can flag anything material up to that date only (likely incomplete for your 12‑month window).

Also tell me if you want me to focus on any jurisdiction (LSE listing, Johannesburg, NYSE) or include all.
